ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Effects of silver nanoparticles towards the efficiency of organic solar cells

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Photonics Research Centre, Faculty of Science
Low Dimensional Material Research Centre, Physics Department

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: We report an alternative approach to enhance the optical and electrical performance of a vanadyl 2,9,16,23-tetraphenoxy-29H,31H-phthalocyanine:poly(3hexylthiophene) (VOPcPhO:P3HT) blending system by integrating plasmonic spherical silver into an active layer of organic solar cells. Studies of the influence of the size distribution and optical properties of the silver nanoparticles were carried out using UV–Vis spectroscopy and field emission scanning electron microscopy, respectively. Electrical characteristics with and without the presence of metallic nanostructures were analyzed using J–V characteristics to observe the plasmonic effects on the performance in the VOPcPhO:P3HT organic solar cells.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: The use of metallic nanostructures in order to enhance performance of devices has been explored many years ago [1–3]. Plasmonics concerns properties of collective electronic excitations, known as surface plasmons in thin films or nanostructures of noble metals (Au, Ag, Cu) [4]. Since particularly physical and chemical properties emerging from metallic nanoparticles are quite different from bulk materials, various nanoscale devices with an application of metallic nanoparticles are in fast development based on the localized surface plasmon effect [5]. Many new technologies have emerged in which the use of plasmonics seems promising, including thermally assisted magnetic recording, thermal cancer treatment, catalysis and nanostructure growth, solar cells, sensors and actuators, and computer chips [6–12].

For improving the application of plasmonics, the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) in a device can be tailored as its strength depends on the shape, size, and distribution of the metal nanoparticles [11]. For thin film silver particle fabrication, various methods can be used such as thermal evaporation [13], radio-frequency (RF) sputtering [14], spray pyrolysis [15], the sol–gel method [16], chemical reduction [17], spin coating [18], ion implantation [19], etc. Plasmonic properties of nanoparticles are characterized by an absorption band in the visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum obtained experimentally employing UV/Vis/NIR spectroscopy [20] or theoretically by using simulation like the discrete-dipole approximation (DDA) [21, 22] and the finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method [23].

Organics proposes major advantages such as the ability to fabricate devices from solutions of the active materials employing cheap, scalable printing techniques with low environmental impact. Introduction to plasmonic metal nanoparticles can be an alternative way of confining light inside the active layer to enhance the absorption in the organic solar cells themselves [11, 24, 25].

A new system of a donor–acceptor blend for a bulk heterojunction solar cell of poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) by using vanadyl 2,9,16,23-tetraphenoxy-29H,31H-phthalocyanine (VOPcPhO) as acceptor material has been fabricated [26]. The P3HT:VOPcPhO blend system was reported to have promising potential to be applied in bulk heterojunction solar cells, due to its high absorption in the solar spectrum in the visible region and considerably good electrical behavior. In this paper, we have integrated silver nanoparticles in this material blend to study the effect of plasmonic silver particles towards the efficiency of the device.

Section1.Heading: Experimental method
Section1.Para:
Silver nanoparticles (Ag NPs) were deposited on ITO-coated glass substrates by using electron beam evaporation (EBE) techniques with a high-vacuum chamber of 2×10−5 torr. The silver pellet target in the crucible was operated at 3.5 kV with 50 mA. The Ag NPs that were deposited on top of the ITO substrates were then annealed at 250 °C for 2 h. The deposited Ag NPs grow in nanosize (10–20 nm) and are distributed uniformly all over the substrate. Devices are fabricated by adding a buffer layer of PEDOT:PSS on ITO substrates (∼10 Ω sheet resistance) employing a spin coating technique at 3000 rpm for 60 s. Samples were then annealed on a hot plate at 120 °C for 30 min. Subsequently, another layer of VOPcPhO:P3HT, which acts as active material, was spun onto the sample at 3000 rpm for 30 s followed by an annealing process at 120 °C for 30 min. The schematic diagram in Fig. 1 shows the fabrication of the device; aluminium top electrodes were deposited by using thermal evaporation operated at 23 A for 1 min in the vacuum chamber. All the processes of fabricating the device were made on the ITO substrates with and without the presence of Ag NPs to compare effects on device efficiency.
Fig. 1
Schematic diagram of VoPcPhO:P3HT organic solar cell embedded with Ag NPs. Al and ITO act as electrodes for the device

Section2.Heading: Size distribution study
Section2.Para:
Figure 2 shows a field emission scanning lectron microscopy (FESEM) image of Ag NPs prepared by the e-beam evaporation technique. After the annealing process, silver nanofilms start to agglomerate and form nanoparticles in sphere-like shape. The analyzed data shows that the sizes range from ∼2 nm to ∼16 nm and are well distributed all over the place, as the interparticle spacings of each particle are about similar. The homogeneity of the Ag NP distribution is important to ensure that plasmonic behavior plays a role all over the area of the solar cell. At wavelengths near the plasmon resonance peak, silver nanoparticles strongly scatter light. This shows that the plasmon behavior arises from the collective oscillation of the free electrons in the metal particle. At this surface plasmon resonance peak, the scattering cross section is found to exceed the geometrical cross section of the particle, thereby increasing the amount of light scattered into the cell [2].
Fig. 2
(a) FESEM image of deposited Ag NPs, (b) calculated size distribution of Ag NPs with Gaussian fit. The nanoparticles may be said to have a very uniform distribution all over the film

Section2.Heading: Optical study
Section2.Para:
UV–visible spectroscopy is one of the most widely used techniques to study the structural characterization of Ag NPs. The absorption spectrum of the resonance peaks is taken on an ITO substrate to ensure that the interaction between the substrate and nanoparticles is minimized. Localized surface plasmons (SPs) are collective oscillations of the conduction electrons in metal particles. Movement of conduction electrons upon excitation with incident light leads to escalation of polarization charges on the particle surfaces. This acts as a restoring force, allowing a resonance to occur at a particular frequency, which is termed the dipole surface plasmon resonance frequency. Incident light that is in the region of the resonance wavelength of the particles is strongly absorbed, depending on the size of the particles [2]. Figure 3 shows the surface plasmon absorption band in the range of 300–750 nm, with an absorption peak at 445 nm and with a broader peak at 645 nm. As there are various sizes of Ag NPs and the interparticle distances are pretty close to each other, this observation arises from coherent coupling between molecular excitons and electronic polarizations of noble-metal nanoparticles. The effects of resonant coupling as a function of spectral overlap were experimentally reported by Wurtz et al. [27], who used J-aggregate molecules on nanowire assemblies with tunable LSPR. The peak at about 325 nm is the peak of ITO-coated glass [28]. Generally, both P3HT and VOPcPhO components lie in the range of 450–750 nm of the visible spectral region. In the P3HT spectrum, a high-energy peak exists at 518 nm. The absorption spectrum of VOPcPhO shows the main absorption at 665 and 715 nm (Q-band) besides the characteristic of Soret absorption bands in the region of 300–500 nm. VOPcPhO is perfectly suited to extend the absorption spectrum of the donor–acceptor blend P3HT:VOPcPhO to a longer wavelength. Figure 4 shows that the blendfilm exhibits an absorption spectrum that includes features of the two components P3HT and VOPcPhO with respect to which the wavelength shifts to the 600–700 nm range. Effectively, from Fig. 4, absorption increases with presence of Ag NPs in comparison to none. As the P3HT:VOPcPhO film is very thick compared to the size of silver nanoparticles, only small changes can be seen in the absorbance, like a small broad peak that arose at about 400 nm and 595 nm wavelengths. This optical measurement with and without metallic structures shows the same trend in Fig. 4, which shows that the small peak at 350 nm is attributed to the region where metals tend to absorb quite strongly. However, overall the existence of silver nanoparticles has made the absorbance peak of P3HT:VOPcPhO seem more prominent. Thus, this is proof that at the surface plasmon resonance peak, the scattering cross section is believed to exceed the geometrical cross section of the particle, thus maximizing the amount of light scattered into the cell.
Fig. 3
Optical absorption for Ag nanoparticles
Fig. 4
Optical absorption for material blend organic solar cell with and without presence of Ag nanoparticles

Section2.Heading: J–V characteristic results
Section2.Para:
The preliminary result shows improvement in VOPcPhO:P3HT organic solar cells (OSCs) with integration of silver (Ag) nanoparticles. Photovoltaic parameters including open-circuit voltage, short-circuit current density, maximum output voltage, maximum output current density, and the maximum output power for both systems have been calculated. Figure 5 shows current density/voltage (J–V) measurements taken under 100 mW cm−2 AM 1.5 illumination for the device with and without presence of Ag NPs. The efficiency of both devices were calculated using the formula
$$\eta= \frac{P_{\max}}{P_{\mathrm{in}}} \times \mathrm{FF} \times100~\%, $$ where
$$\frac{P_{\max}}{P_{\mathrm{in}}} = \frac{J_{\mathrm{sc}} \times V_{\mathrm{oc}}}{100\ \mathrm{mW}/ \mathrm{cm}^{2}} $$ and FF is the fill factor, where
$$\mathrm{FF} = \frac{J_{\max } \times V_{\max }}{J_{\mathrm{sc}} \times V_{\mathrm{oc}}}, $$ where J max, V max, J sc, and V oc are maximum current density, maximum voltage, short-circuit current density and open-circuit voltage, respectively. Table 1 shows that the increment values of current density with respect of the presence of Ag NPs leads to obtained higher efficiency. The comparison values show an efficiency increase of up to 41 % with presence of Ag in the device. It is worth mentioning that the enhancement of light trapping of the device was assisted by the plasmonic properties of silver nanoparticles and shows a factor in contributing to the improvement of efficiency of organic solar cell devices [1, 29].
Fig. 5
Electrical measurement on a plasmonic solar cell. Data shown are comparison of the device with and without presence of Ag nanoparticles
Table 1
Data shown are efficiency characteristics with and without Ag NPs with increase in the efficiency with presence of Ag
J sc (mA/cm2)
V oc (V)
Fill factor
Efficiency (%)
Without Ag NPs
2.98
0.71
0.51
1.09
With Ag NPs
5.03
0.72
0.51
1.86

The presence of plasmonic Ag nanoparticles has contributed a significant increase in current density value but the FF value remains the same. It can be seen that much improvement of efficiency was achieved only from the increase of photocurrent after the addition of Ag nanoparticles used for confining the light inside the active material. A small change in open-circuit voltage that is observed may be due to the effect of a large increase in photocurrent value, and it is believed that the presence of Ag nanoparticles has no significant contribution for the improvement of V oc. With the presence of plasmonic-assisted spherical nanoparticles within the active material layer, the efficiency has risen from 1.09 to 1.86 %. A conduction mechanism for this plasmonic solar cell has been investigated by studying its space-charge-limited current region where the value of mobility can be obtained from the following expression:
$$J=\ \frac{9}{8} \varepsilon \varepsilon_{0} \theta\mu \frac{V^{2}}{d^{3}}, $$ where ε is the relative permittivity of the organic material with a value of 3, ε 0 is the permittivity of free space, θ is the trap factor that can be obtained from the experiment (θ=J 1/J 2), μ is the value of the charge carrier mobility across the junction of the device, and d is the thickness of effective material between two electrodes.

From Fig. 6, a double-logarithmic plot of current density (J) vs. voltage (V) has shown two main conduction regions where the first region with slope ∼1 is the ohmic conduction regime and the second region with slope 2 is the SCLC conduction regime. The SCLC starts to appear between 1 and 2 V where the mobility value is calculated from this region and found to be 0.39×10−5 cm2/V s. The SCLC mobility measurement is taken from the same plasmonic cell device after a few weeks when I–V characterization was carried out. It is believed that this mobility is reduced after the device aging has occurred, but the value is considerably sufficient (10−5–10−4 cm2/V s) for solar cell application.
Fig. 6
The physical conduction mechanism on double-logarithmic scale of J vs. V

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: Silver nanoparticles have been deposited and were introduced to the high-potential material blend VOPcPhO:P3HT. The presence of silver nanoparticles in the VOPcPhO:P3HT film has given very significant impacts towards its optical and electrical properties. The size distribution and homogeneity of the silver nanoparticle film produce a good trend of surface plasmon resonance behavior of the particles. This behavior leads towards the improvement of the performance of the charge-carrying activity of the VOPcPhO:P3HT blend system. Thus, this result can be further used for photovoltaic application where more theoretical study will be carried out for better understanding of light trapping of these particles.

Acknowledgments.Heading: Acknowledgement
Acknowledgments.SimplePara: This work has been supported with the PPP Grant Nos. PG060-2012B, RP 008E-13AET, and RU002/2013.
